title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message: have another 820-00165 with green light and no fan spin this time. no sign of liquid damage. initially PRAM reset worked but then it died again. already checked around ISL and pins 17/18 etc. and have normal values (low resistance)

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message: Post basic voltages and signals...

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message:
PP3v42 = 3.4
PPVRTC 3.3
PP5V_S5 5v
PP3V3_S5 3.3
PP3V3_SUS 3.3

U7100 pin 27/28 20 ohms

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message:
Poste exact voltage for PPBUS_G3H.
Check if any of PM_SLP_Sx_L signals pulses when trigger SMC_ONOFF_L.

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message:
PPbus G3h is 8.58

When you say trigger SMC, how do i do that? or is that just plugging it in?

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message: none of the PM_SLP_ are pulsing hmm

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message:
Use R5115/16 pads for that.
I prefer to solder a tiny wire on SMC_ONOFF_L and simulate power button touching some metal plate from chassis...
PM_PWRBTN_L must react then. PM_RSMRST_L should be high, of course.
Check if PCH receives 32KHz oscillation.

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message:
Hmm i think SMC on/off is doing nothing. am not getting anything on PM_PWRBTN_L  on PM_RSMRST_L it's always 3.3

How would I check PCH for oscillation? im a noob! haha

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message:
PM_PWRBTN_L stays always at 3V?
You should catch a drop pulse when simulate power button.

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message: Must've been a bad connection because PM_PWRBTN_L works now. 3.4v normal and then 0.36v when simulating power press

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message: So that's working as expected?

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message:
Yes, check now if PM_SLP_S5/4/3_L react too.
Use o-scope, or repeatedly trigger SMC_ONOFF_L if use DC multimeter only.

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message: Ok so the S4 sometimes i catch the multimeter going up to 0.025v when triggering just for a second s3 does nothing it appears I think. and neither does s5. something interesting I found accidentally. when triggering power press once, I was accidentally measuring S5_pwrgd and it was pulsing from 0v to 3.3 v constantly until it was eventually stable at 3v. not sure if relevant

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message:
S5_PWRGD should be high before board starts; depends by 3V3_S5.
SMC generates PM_DSW_PWRGD in base of it.
The sleep reactions should be ordered as S5 -> S4 -> S3.
If PM_PWRBTN_L reacts, no sleep reaction will point to PCH.
But you must be sure if no reaction at all.
Catch a cheap analog second hand o-scope; it is good enough for this job.
I don't recommend mini DSO bullshits...
You must also assure PCH gets all necessary signals to power on.

message: Which is the PCH? I can see many different ones on the schematic? Do you think it's fixable with Osciliscope and patience?

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message:
I think i have good news! i soldered a bigger wire to smc_onoff, and PM_SLP_S5_L and PM_SLP_S4_L are consistently responding to rapid triggering s5 goes to 0.002 and s4 goes to 0.03 consistently.

However PM_SLP_S3_L is not responding at all. it's dead

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message:
On DC scale you must get more than 1V, normally more than 2V pulse when trigger it...
PM_PWRBTN_L reacts with drop pulse close to 0V?

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message: PM_PWRBTN_L reacts and drops from 3.4v to 0.3v. is that close enough?

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message: That's good, but you must get more evident reaction at sleep signals.

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message: so oscilloscope is necessary now?

title: 820-00165 green light, no fan spin
message: If you cannot confirm sleep reaction, start checking basic signals for PCH.
